_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Per the requirements of Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 as codified in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Part 68, this Risk Management Program (RMP) plan is submitted to the United States Environmental Protection Agency (U.S. EPA) in a timely manner for the Associated Grocers, Inc., (AG) facility in Seattle, Washington.

STATIONARY SOURCE & REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
AG owns and operates a facility located in Seattle, Washington, that handles anhydrous ammonia, a substance which is considered hazardous by the U.S. EPA.  Anhydrous ammonia is used by AG as a refrigerant in the facility's perishables warehouse.  The maximum quantity of ammonia that can be stored or handled in the perishables warehouse refrigeration system is 25,000 pounds.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM & CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
AG has a prevention program in place that complies with the requirements of the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) program for prevention of accidental releases of ammonia.  The release prevention program includes all the required elements for PSM, including a management system, process safety information, a process hazard analysis, operating procedures, an operator training program, a mechanical integrity program, management of change procedures, pre-startup review, internal compliance audits, incident investigations, employee participation, and contractor safety program. 

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
No reportable accidents occurred in the last five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
AG maintains a written emergency action plan to safely respond to accidental releases of hazardous substances and other emergencies at the perishables warehouse.  The plan identifies personnel roles at the facility (Incident Commanders, Emergency Response Coordinators, First Responders / Evacuation Coordinators) for handling the emergency and responsibilities for each of the personnel roles.  These responsibilities include notif

ication of HazMat team, sounding evacuation alarms, evacuation of building (including sweeps of building), controlling access to evacuated area, and procedures to follow in case of a medical emergency.  The plan also specifies that evacuation drills be conducted at least annually.
